message:
Artbeat 2018
Get enchanted by the creativity presented at Artbeat, the annual art exhibition organized by Spectra-The Fine Arts and Design group of IIT Kharagpur from 24th to 26th March during 10AM-10PM at Assembly Hall, Technology Student's Gymkhana. We strongly urge you to visit lest you miss out on all the marvels presented.
#Artbeat2018

In an attempt to build indigenous technologies for commercial usage our institute is working on developing an ecosystem of budding technical entrepreneurs. One such project on Rain and Fog removal from Video Sequences has been taken up by Prof. Sudipta Mukhopadhyay and his team. Patents have been filed in US, Europe and South Korea. Basic application has been shown to work and is being approached by the world top leaders in Defence and Transportation. To scale up the work and improve the commercial viability of the product interns are being hired to work in the following related fields. Interested and enthusiastic students are invited to fill in the google form below. They will be invited to the recruitment drive soon.

https://goo.gl/forms/Dn5ilhGnEbnmse2g2

Interns required in the following domains : Product Development, Android Programming, CUDA C, Image Processing, Machine Learning

Eligibility : Anyone interested is invited
Time Period : Summers 2018 and beyond
Stipend : Will be provided on the basis of alloted work

For any queries you can contact Professor Sudipta Mukhopadhyay, Department of E&ECE, IIT Kharagpur.

Their popularity rises exponentially as the exams approach. Yes, we are referring to the class of people fondly(begrudgingly, in some cases) known as Maggus. Presenting the second instalment of our Anatomy series, "The Anatomy of a Maggu". We implore you to use the comments section to roast your Maggu friends, but be careful lest you touch a nerve. As Bill Gates once said, "Be nice to nerds. Chances are you'll end up working for one."

To set the record straight, The Scholars' Avenue talked to a few professors at the department of Humanities and Social Sciences about the importance of these discplines for technically trained graduates. Here's what they had to tell us.

message:
Nobody has any doubts over how convenient a bicycle is on the campus (no wonder we have so many psyclepaths* on the campus). Nevertheless, cycles have a reputation for being a pain in the neck. Cyclogists* at The Scholars' Avenue, after having done extensive research, present you, "The Anatomy of a KGP Bicycle". We request bikeaholics* to not get offended.

*psyclepaths = people who love cycles.
*bikeaholic = same as above.
*Cyclogists, ok, at this point, it is clear that we are just showing off our skill at pun making.

Final Day | Quiz Week
Sci-Tech and Pop-culture Quiz

The last day of the quiz week had the least number of attendants, so much so that the number of teams in the finals had to be lowered down to 7 and 5 to maintain competitiveness. The Quizzes, however, maintained their standards and the questions were spread across the board in both the quizzes.

Sci-Tech Quiz Results: 
First: Piyush Kedia, Kaniska Ghosh, Rishiraj Bose (225)
Second: Mayank Roy, Rupam Kumar Dubey, Adithya Srikanth (220)
Third: Girish Suranje, Harsha Vattem, Robin Babu P (185)

Pop-Culture Quiz Results:
First: Amit Kumar Ram, Girish Suranje, Kaustav Mandal (188)
Second: Baibhab Pattnaik, Sangeeta Roy, Lakshay Singhal (177)
Third: Abhimanyu Bharade, Prachurjya Biswas, Kaniska Ghosh (156)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club for a successful quiz week.

Since we didn't have photos for the sessions, the quiz set in the pop-culture quiz run by Hemansh and Mayank Roy is being shared instead. :)
P.S: Give the List-its in the finals a try 

Finals: https://www.slideshare.net/iitkgpquizclub/pop-culture-quizfinals

Prelims: https://www.slideshare.net/iitkgpquizclub/pop-culture-prelimsanswers-90391384

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 9 new photos.
message:
General Quiz and Biz Quiz | Quiz Week Day 5

Day 5 saw a very busy day with quizzes after quizzes going on at Vikramshila. General Quiz started early in the afternoon with people gathering being treated with a dose of everything in the world. After that, the Biz Quiz took place in the evening and saw a very topsy-turvy finale with the final spots getting chosen in the final few questions.

Results:
General Quiz:
First: Amit Kumar Ram, Agnimitra Anand, Pranav Joshi (260)
Second: Piyush Kedia, Rupam Kumar Dubey, Vaibhav Krishna (210)
Third: Kaustav Mandal, Kaniska Ghosh + 1 (205)

Biz Quiz:
First: Piyush Kedia, Kaustav Mandal, Anmol Joshi (270)
Second: Sourav Chirania, Harsha Vattem, Siddhant Ladha (240)
Third: Amit Kumar Ram, Anurag Mondal, Shubhra Agrawal (230)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates all the winners and wishes IIT KGP Quiz Club best of luck for the last day of the Quiz Week tomorrow.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 3 new photos.
message:
MELA Quiz | Quiz Week Day 4

Day 4 saw a lot of the MELA enthusiasts in the campus turn up for the quiz which turned out to be a very entertaining, exciting and close affair right down till the last question when the podium was finally decided.
This time around, all the participants who qualified from the prelims stayed back to sit for the finals and made the event a success.

First: Agnimitra Anand, Kaniska Ghosh, Mayank Roy
Second: R. Srihari, Anurag Kar, Prachurjya Biswas
Third: Mohit Tulsyan, Nikhil Nayan Jha, Varun PD

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and the QMs on an exciting quiz and wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club the best of luck for the four quizzes to be held in the next two days.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 4 new photos — with Bindu Sancheti and Shweta Jaiswal.
message:
Women's Quiz | Quiz Week Day 3

Day 3, a veritable first for KGP quizzing in many ways saw a women-only quiz being conducted with 25 participants, which, compared to the norm of 2-3 women in regular quizzes was a huge improvement. It continued the trend of first-timers leaving right after prelims without waiting for the results for yet another day in a row where the third member of the (later on)first place team left, assuming she wouldn't qualify. Considering that almost all of the participants being first-time quizzers, the scores received in the prelims and finals results were very competitive.
The aim of the event had been to try and introduce women to the sport and the response, especially in the finals from teams was very positive, with blocks and enthusiastic hint requests and clarifications going around on questions. The finals boiled down to a tie-breaker for third place and after three further tie-breaker questions which couldn't break the tie, the third place remained tied till the end in the final result.
Prof. Seema Singh of the HSS department also graced the event with her presence and stayed almost till the end of the quiz.

First: Sangeeta Roy, Shubhra Agrawal (225)
Second: Ayushi Mrigen, Nikita Gautam, Kavana Rao (135)
Third: Shubhi Jain, Abhigna Revuru, Nayan Kubade (130) and
Pankhuri Saxena, Samruddhi Pataskar and Pankhudi Jain (130)
Fourth: (125)
Fifth: (120)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and hopes that this helps somewhat bridge the gender disparity in quizzing in the campus and further wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club best of luck for the future quizzes in this event.

Prof. Seema Singh of the HSS department also graced the event with her presence and stayed almost till the end of the quiz.

First: Sangeeta Roy, Shubhra Agrawal (225)
Second: Ayushi Mrigen, Nikita Gautam, Kavana Rao (135)
Third: Shubhi Jain, Abhigna Revuru, Nayan Kubade (130) and
Pankhuri Saxena, Samruddhi Pataskar and Pankhudi Jain (130)
Fourth: (125)
Fifth: (120)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and hopes that this helps somewhat bridge the gender disparity in quizzing in the campus and further wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club best of luck for the future quizzes in this event.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 4 new photos — with Bindu Sancheti and Shweta Jaiswal.
message:
Women's Quiz | Quiz Week Day 3

Day 3, a veritable first for KGP quizzing in many ways saw a women-only quiz being conducted with 25 participants, which, compared to the norm of 2-3 women in regular quizzes was a huge improvement. It continued the trend of first-timers leaving right after prelims without waiting for the results for yet another day in a row where the third member of the (later on)first place team left, assuming she wouldn't qualify. Considering that almost all of the participants being first-time quizzers, the scores received in the prelims and finals results were very competitive.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 2 new photos.
message:
India Quiz | Quiz Week: Day 2

Day 2 in the Intra-KGP Quiz Week saw an even higher participation from the KGP population, with similar scenes occurring with first timers as day one. Another prelims participant had to miss out because of low self-confidence about his own talent because he left for his hall without leaving any contact info.
Both the prelims and finals were highly entertaining, with all the three podium places getting cleared out in the final three questions of the quiz with all the other teams chasing just 5-15 points behind.
The point of female participation came up again today, but this time, there was some participation from the female populace and one of them even making it to the finals.

First: Harsh Agarwal, Pinaki Mishra, Sourav Kundu (180)
Second: Sourav Chirania, Baibhab Pattnaik, Kaniska Ghosh (150)
Third: Satyam Agarwal, Pratik Gokul Zaware, Shreyans Sadangi (145)
Fourth, Fifth, Sixth: (140)
 
The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club all the best for today's Women Only Quiz.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 2 new photos.
message:
Sports Quiz | Quiz Week : Day 1

Today saw the participation of close to 70 people for the prelims and we saw the greatest fear of most non-quizzers coming up in action and tackled head-on.
Two people out of the 24 finalists scored higher than Quiz Club regulars and yet, because they thought they hadn't done well enough, left without even waiting for the results. One of them didn't submit their contact details so we couldn't even reach them to let them know and hence had to take the next highest scorer present. We later got to know that there were two-three people who didn't want to see if they could qualify and didn't submit their answer sheet for checking, where it turned out that they would've actually qualified for the finals. The team that won actually had a member like that, who after giving up, decided to go to his room, from where he had to be called to come back for the finals and eventually won. The finals itself was a cliffhanger with the podium places getting decided in the last two questions of the quiz.

Furthermore, there were no women in attendance. An event, that has no barriers to entry, and no prerequisites for taking part, as well as cash prizes and refreshments where non-regulars to QC sessions turned up and performed very well had an entire section of our campus population giving it a miss in participation definitely speaks volumes about this. We invite discussion regarding this in the comments section, and more than discussion, ideas to improve this situation, considering that Quiz Club has brought laurels for the institute in multiple places throughout the past years and their current Quiz Week initiative is an attempt to lure in people who don't consider themselves knowledgeable enough.

Final Results:

First: B. Pattnaik, Bhart Singh, Sougata Paul (135)
Second: Agnimitra Anand, Piyush Kedia, Hemansh Kashyap (120)
Third: Amit Kumar Ram, Rajat Jain, Kaushal Vadera (118)
Fourth Place: (115)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and wishes Quiz Club all the best for the rest of the quizzes to be held as part of Quiz Week.

message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Business Club, IIT Kharagpur's post. Greetings! ZS associates in collaboration with Business Club brings to you an open house session -“Brown Bag on the Art and Science of Problem-Solving”. It will focus on understanding the most effective approaches of solving a case study. This session will also act as an introduction to the case study competition to be organized by ZS, winners of which will get Pre-Placement Interview (PPI) offers from ZS! What to wait for? Embark on the journey of honing your skills and begin your expedition into the fascinating world of consulting that might just hold your future. We have exciting goodies and refreshments that await your presence. This session is exclusively for pre-final year students. Since limited number of seats are available, register at: https://tinyurl.com/y989quod 7 PM, 6th March | V4 For any queries please contact: Puneet: 9783611967 Aman: 7430011888

Heartiest congratulations to Mr. Shreshth Khare and Mr. Sanskar Rawat, third-year undergraduates of the Department of Chemical Engineering for winning the 8th edition of EXL Excellence Quotient (EQ) data case challenge. The competition is held across 20 top engineering institutes including 8 IITs and 7 NITs. A total of 680 teams registered for the competition and after two stages of submissions, top 6 teams were invited to present their case in the National Finals at EXL Head Office, Gurgaon. Ms. Anjali Bharti and  Mr. Anshul Gupta from IIT Kharagpur working under the Team title "Panacea "  also secured their position in the National finals.

The winning team, Team Insidious from IIT Kharagpur received a cash prize of Rs. 1 Lakh along with certificates and winning trophy. Pre-placement interview offer was extended to all the 6 teams who made it to the National Finals.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 2 new photos.
message:
Ankur Mehta, a fourth-year B.Tech student from Department of Chemical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur has won the Best Oral Presentation Award at the International Conference on Clean and Green Energy(ICCGE) held in Paris, France on February 7-9, 2018 for his presentation titled "Kinetics of delignification and Enzymatic Hydrolysis of non-food lignocellulose for Cellulosic Biofuel Production". 

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates him and wishes him all the best for the future. It is great to see the growing culture of research among undergraduate students and we hope to see many more of such accomplishments.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 33 new photos — with Manorama Jha and 5 others.
message:
Safety Analytics and Virtual Reality lab in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering invited The Scholars' Avenue to showcase their work and projects. Established in May 2016 under the mentorship of the Prof Partha P Chakrabarti, Director IIT Kharagpur, and under the charge of Prof Jhareswar Maiti, Head of Department, Industrial and Systems Engineering, the SAVR Lab has state of the art facilities to carry out research in Virtual Reality. The lab is equipped with the essential tools such as 3D laser scanners, military-grade head-mounted displays, oculus rifts, data gloves, powerful computers, projectors etc. The lab has been sponsored by the Government of India under the Uchhatar Avishkar Yojana (UAY) to promote Virtual Reality research.
 
Their “hero project”, for all the Elon Musk fans out there, is a Virtual Reality [VR] simulation of SpaceX’s Star-man created by Prateek Srivastava [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Ocean Engineering and Naval Architecture]. 
 
A team of 10 students including Manorama Jha[research scholar] and Siddharth Jindal [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Mathematics and Computing]  led by Prateek and mentored by Mr. Anirban Santara [PhD scholar and a 2015 B.Tech graduate, Department of Electronics and Electrical Communications Engineering], who is popular in the Artificial Intelligence community of Kharagpur, are working on the Virtual KGP project, a complete open-source VR simulation of the campus which they hope will help in initiating other projects for development of different VR applications. To aid the completion of the project they intend to organize various hackathons where students will be awarded for adding intricate details. They aim to collaborate with the Urban Planning Department of IIT Kharagpur in making an app which will help regional planners visualize their designs. With Autonomous Ground Vehicle, IIT Kharagpur they plan to create a highly accurate and photorealistic simulation of an autonomous car through an open sourced project- the first of its kind in the world.
 
The lab has also taken up a project sponsored by Tata Steel to simulate the Electric Overhead Travelling [EOT] Crane in the hope of reducing industrial accidents and improving safety standards. Recognising the scope for research in Virtual Reality in various sectors like education, industry, and entertainment, they are encouraging Virtual Reality research in the campus and are inviting B.Tech and M.Tech students to take up projects in their lab. 
 
The lab invites students to come in small groups to catch a glimpse of their SpaceX's Star-man simulation.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 33 new photos — with Manorama Jha and 5 others.
message:
Safety Analytics and Virtual Reality lab in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering invited The Scholars' Avenue to showcase their work and projects. Established in May 2016 under the mentorship of the Prof Partha P Chakrabarti, Director IIT Kharagpur, and under the charge of Prof Jhareswar Maiti, Head of Department, Industrial and Systems Engineering, the SAVR Lab has state of the art facilities to carry out research in Virtual Reality. The lab is equipped with the essential tools such as 3D laser scanners, military-grade head-mounted displays, oculus rifts, data gloves, powerful computers, projectors etc. The lab has been sponsored by the Government of India under the Uchhatar Avishkar Yojana (UAY) to promote Virtual Reality research.
 
Their “hero project”, for all the Elon Musk fans out there, is a Virtual Reality [VR] simulation of SpaceX’s Star-man created by Prateek Srivastava [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Ocean Engineering and Naval Architecture]. 
 
A team of 10 students including Manorama Jha[research scholar] and Siddharth Jindal [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Mathematics and Computing]  led by Prateek and mentored by Mr. Anirban Santara [PhD scholar and a 2015 B.Tech graduate, Department of Electronics and Electrical Communications Engineering], who is popular in the Artificial Intelligence community of Kharagpur, are working on the Virtual KGP project, a complete open-source VR simulation of the campus which they hope will help in initiating other projects for development of different VR applications. To aid the completion of the project they intend to organize various hackathons where students will be awarded for adding intricate details. They aim to collaborate with the Urban Planning Department of IIT Kharagpur in making an app which will help regional planners visualize their designs. With Autonomous Ground Vehicle, IIT Kharagpur they plan to create a highly accurate and photorealistic simulation of an autonomous car through an open sourced project- the first of its kind in the world.
 
The lab has also taken up a project sponsored by Tata Steel to simulate the Electric Overhead Travelling [EOT] Crane in the hope of reducing industrial accidents and improving safety standards. Recognising the scope for research in Virtual Reality in various sectors like education, industry, and entertainment, they are encouraging Virtual Reality research in the campus and are inviting B.Tech and M.Tech students to take up projects in their lab. 
 
The lab invites students to come in small groups to catch a glimpse of their SpaceX's Star-man simulation.

The first weekend of this month witnessed an influx of eminent personalities in the fields of business and entrepreneurial ventures thanks to the Global Entrepreneurship Summit organised by Entrepreneurship Cell, IIT Kharagpur. Among them, Mr.Gulzar Azad was one of the guest speakers invited to share his experiences. We thank them for giving us a chance to interact with him.

Mr. Azad is the present connectivity head of Google India. One look at his profile will speak of his rich experience of working in different kinds of environments and his steady rise. We were glad to have an exciting chat with him on various topics, mainly his iconic RailWire Project, the fruits of which can be seen in the form of free wifi not only here at the Kharagpur Railway Station but all over the country and his experience of working with Google with respect to the entrepreneurial and networking opportunities it opened up for him. He had a lot of interesting things to say on this front and much more.

Check out the link below to share some of his thoughts on several topics ranging from intrepreneurship, free Wi-Fi to how Google shaped him into what he is today.

 https://youtu.be/69NctEpzNUI

story: The Scholars' Avenue added a new photo.
message:
"People often say that motivation doesn't last. Well, neither does bathing. That's why we recommend it daily."
- Zig Ziglar
Starting the Graph Theory for this semester with one of the most distinctive traits of our breed of engineers, a tradition rooted in the annals of history and followed ardently even today. May there be a time when the art of bathing, or not rather, becomes your badge of honour . Till then here's a something you can refer to. 
Does it represent you? Let us know what you think in the comments.

After series of tests at the CIC Lab, the Technology Transfer Group in association with the Sponsored Research and Industry Consultancy (SRIC) has officially launched the Undergraduate Research Portal today at the Netaji Auditorium. Prof.  S K Barai (Dean UGS) and Prof. Sriman Bhattacharya (Deputy Director) were present there along with few other Professors who gave an insight to the research fields and enumerated the research groups developed at IIT Kharagpur. The portal aims at promoting research among Undergrads, who can now apply for projects to work during their summer/ winter vacations. There was a demonstration in which a professor, Dumbledore floats a project topic of research, "The Sorting Hat Algorithm." Harry and Draco, the students, apply by filling the form through their student accounts in the portal and uploading a CV. Based on the applications, Draco gets rejected, and Harry selected who then starts to work on the project.
This initiative could tailor young minds towards research, thus bringing about a much-needed evolution in the research culture at IIT KGP.

In an effort to brighten up the lives of less fortunate children, the IIT Kharagpur chapter of CRY has joined forces with Anthill Playscapes, started by an IIT KGP alumnus, which focuses on making playgrounds for children in a unique way by using cost-effective practices such as industrial waste and localized sourcing techniques.

The collaboration of CRY and Anthill wants to ensure that all the children have fun and excitement in their lives and therefore they are hoping to raise INR 1,25,000 to support the kids from the Amlatoria school, one of their adopted schools from a nearby village. They do not have a playground right now and the amount you donate will go in giving the children a playful and memorable childhood.

Please click the following link to donate and know more.

https://anthillcreations.ketto.org/fundraiser/CRYiitkgpAnthill?utm_source=campaigner&utm_medium=fbpageshare&utm_campaign=CRYiitkgpAnthill&utm_content=38348

National Misson on Education through Communication and Information Technology (NMEICT), Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) has awarded IIT Kharagpur Phase-II of the project to develop a National Digital Library (NDLI). The project to develop a pilot for NDLI was also awarded to IIT Kharagpur which was completed well before the scheduled time. This is the primary reason why IIT Kharagpur was awarded the second phase. Visit https://ndl.iitkgp.ac.in/ to register and have a look at the beta version of NDLI.

Phase-II of the project aims to develop the Pilot to a full-fledged NDLI with an aim to build a National Asset. This project will enable some key national knowledge discovery and immersive learning platforms built around the Digital Library. It will also encourage the entrepreneurial development of tools and apps around this platform. In its final contour, the system may serve as a pan-India virtual teaching-learning-evaluation-knowledge discovery and innovation platform, evolving as a key National Asset.
    
NDLI is getting structured along verticals like School, Competitive Exams and Career Development, Engineering, Medical, Law, etc. Under the Competitive Exams & Career Development vertical, NDLI is going to make available solutions (with explanations, alternate solutions, reference study materials and annotations) to all IIT-JEE Question Papers (since 2007) to benefit a large number of IIT-JEE aspirants.

The project is, thus, inviting applications from students who are currently in their 1st year of studies (Engineering, Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics) and are willing to work as part-time Intern to prepare Solutions for JEE Question Papers. Suitable financial compensation will be provided.
The selection for the internship will be made by the PI/Co-PIs of the project and will be based on academic records.

Interested students must submit their particulars at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ExbMob88xpmYbA5GensJrohXd0bHfqTgSoxZmORBYTM/edit#gid=304908349.
The applications will be considered till 23:55 hours, Wednesday, 11th February 2018.

The project is, thus, inviting applications from students who are currently in their 1st year of studies (Engineering, Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics) and are willing to work as part-time Intern to prepare Solutions for JEE Question Papers. Suitable financial compensation will be provided.
The selection for the internship will be made by the PI/Co-PIs of the project and will be based on academic records.

Interested students must submit their particulars at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ExbMob88xpmYbA5GensJrohXd0bHfqTgSoxZmORBYTM/edit#gid=304908349.
The applications will be considered till 23:55 hours, Wednesday, 11th February 2018.

Heartiest congratulations to the three recipients of Honda Y-E-S Award 2017-2018 from IIT Kharagpur. The award was conferred to Mr. Piyush Nanda, Department of Biotechnology, Ms. Bindu Sancheti, Department of Chemical Engineering and Mr. Ayan Majumder, Department of Mechanical Engineering on 25th January 2018 after a four-stage selection process. Every year, the award is conferred to 14 students across 6 IITs. The objective of the award is to felicitate meritorious students in the field of science and technology.
Each Y-E-S Award recipient received US$ 3,000 (US Dollar Three Thousand only) in equivalent Indian Rupees and a credit-granting summer internship program offered by a Japanese company or research institute for two and half months. 
An additional of US$ 7,000 will be granted for pursuing the internship in Japan.
For further information, please visit the site:
http://yes.honda.co.in/
An introductory seminar will be conducted next semester for the same.

NOTICE 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On the recommendation of the Undergraduate Programme Evaluation Committee, the Senate at its 323rd meeting held on 22nd December 2017, approved the following revised rules/guidelines for B.Tech Project (BTP) with effect from Academic Session 2018-2019.

1) The B.Tech project will be optional. BTP-I will be of 3 credits and BTP-II will be of 6 credits.

2) Allotment of projects will be done once the list of students who opt for BTP will be available in the 6th semester.

3) If a student opted BTP-I in Autumn Semester, then the faculty supervisor should inform whether BTP-II is necessary in the Spring semester.

4) After Autumn Semester, the student will have two options:
       I. The student can continue with BTP-II as an extension of 
          BTP-I in the Spring Semester, OR
      II. The student will be allowed to take theory subjects of 
          equivalent credit in the Spring Semester in lieu of BTP-II, if 
          there is no condition attached by faculty supervisor at the 
          beginning.

5) A student who does not opt for BTP must take subjects of equivalent credit in both Autumn and Spring semesters.

6) A student can also register for B.Tech projects in other departments (with necessary approval of the Head of the Department in which he/she is originally enrolled, and the Head of the Department in which he/she wants to pursue B.Tech project), and in that case, the project will be evaluated by the department where the student is pursuing the project in both the semesters.

IIT Kharagpur conferred the first ever Learn-Earn-Return Fellow Award to 3 of its 1st-year students. The award was instituted by Prof P P Chakrabarti, Director IIT Kharagpur, IIT Kharagpur, in July 2016 with the funding crowdsourced from the alumni. Jyoti Agrawal, Jyotisman Das and Rathin Singha from the Department of Computer Science and Engineering were the recipients. The fellow award was conferred on the occasion of the Annual Alumni Meet on January 13, 2018 in the presence of about 300 alumni who came from India and abroad.

Each of the students will receive Rs. 10000/- per month for 4 years as a cash award. At the end of the first semester of the 1st year, it will be awarded based on JEE Advanced rank. From second semester onward the recipients of the award would have to maintain a CGPA 9.

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the students and hopes these awards would bloom into a beautiful support system between our alumni and our students. 

Read on to know more:
http://alumni.iitkgp.ac.in/content/iitkgp-students-pledge-learn-earn-and-return

The 15th Annual Alumni meet has officially began! Day 1 of the three day event began with a campus tour followed by a departmental visit. A 'Musical Night' was organised in which the a few alumni of the '93 batch who had a band named 'Still Waters' took to the stage to perform some age old classics after a gap of 25 years. The performance was scintillating!

Approximately 300 alumni, from the batches of '68, '78, and '93, are enjoying their return back to campus.

One of the alumni who was also a part of the Springfest organising committee expressed his jubilation on coming back for the first time since graduation. 
"A lot has changed. There are roads and pathways everywhere. Boys are definitely more disciplined than we were. I wish I could have those days back", he told The Scholars' Avenue.

Day 1 of the meet will come to an end with the much anticipated hall visits.

Inter IIT Tech 2018 :

IIT Kharagpur has won the overall Gold and yet again proved its mettle. The winning streak continues after the Silver last year and Gold in 2015 and 2016. 

The participants have displayed a phenomenal performance and we're glad the hard work has paid off. The event-wise scores are as follows:

Engineer's Conclave: 192.1052632
Safety Device for Fishing Vessels: 0
Exoplanet Detection: 60
Case Study: 100
Optimal Bidding: 100
Automatic Toilet Cleaning: 100
Warehouse Inventory: 100
Fiducial Localisation: 100
Orbital Simulator: 100
Technology for Soldier Support: 0
Total score: 832.1052632

We were followed by IIT Roorkee (668.4210526) and IIT Madras (650).

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the whole contingent for emerging victorious with flying colors.

A month back, we published a GuestAve by an IIT Kharagpur Alumnus who had been involved in the starting and formalization of the Tech GC and how he perceived a disconnect in its structure with the world and the needs of 'Technology' in the industry, country and with the vision of IITs.

It garnered an amazing response from our readers with points and counter-points which prompted Dr. Aloke to present his own views on the topic and how he perceives the GC morphing into something that he considers a necessity for the India of tomorrow, in a transition from being just a 'Tech GC' to becoming a stepping stone for a career in 'Tech' that IIT originally claims to provide.

The Scholars'​ Avenue hopes that more sessions and events like these will be organised to give the budding poets and literati a new platform to showcase their talent and spread this vibrant culture.

The Warwick Manufacturing Group (WMG) at the University of Warwick, founded by Indian-origin engineer-educator Kumar Bhattacharyya, has been officially conferred the prestigious Regius Professorship, given by the British queen to recognise exceptionally high quality research.
Bhattacharyya, who is also a member of the House of Lords, is an alumnus of IIT Kharagpur.

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates him on this occasion.

Hey everyone, 

This just in today morning,The MHRD set up a three-member committee headed by IIT-Kharagpur Director Partha Pratim Chakraborty on Tuesday to suggest ways to reduce the number of seats falling vacant at IITs and NITs every year. The move comes in the wake of almost 3,000 seats falling vacant this year despite six rounds of joint counselling for the IITs, NITs and centrally funded technical institutions. Of these, 73 seats were lying vacant at the IITs and 1,518 at the NITs.

We are eager to see what the committee comes up with.

http://indianexpress.com/article/delhi/hrd-panel-to-check-vacancies-at-iits-nits-3066218/

On the occasion of the conclusion of Great Step (The Mining Engg. Festival) last weekend, two of The Scholars' Avenue reporters came across a very jubilant bunch of students with a trophy. They turned out to be the overall champions of the fest, students of AKS University, Satna. Their performance was great in the events such as Mine Indite, Mineac, Geobotics and 1st Campus Ambassador. One of the senior members of the team quoted, "We are feeling very proud and glad after winning the championship trophy. Thanks to IIT KGP for providing such a good platform for showcasing our talent."

story: The Scholars' Avenue shared Director IIT Kharagpur's photo.
message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Director IIT Kharagpur's photo. Prof M A Rege, ex-HoD Department of Architecture & Regional Planning, IIT Kharagpur is no more. Fondly remembered by many students and admirers. Amherst - Madhukar Anant Rege passed away at age 92, on September 20th, 2016, after a long illness and a long, full life on three continents. Born in Ratnagiri on the Konkan Coast of India, he had a happy, active childhood. From an early age he loved drawing and painting and eventually earned a Diploma in Architecture at the J.J. School of Art in Bombay, after apprenticing for a year with the master watercolorist Sawlaram Haldankar. In 1949, at age 25, he set sail for England with the help of his eldest brother Vinayak, where he successfully sat the R.I.B.A. (Royal Institute of British Architects) examination and then completed a post-graduate Diploma in Town Planning. It was in England that he met and married Gladys Sharp on July 4th, 1953, and, after the birth of their first daughter in 1954, returned to India, where he took up a lectureship in Architecture at the newly formed Indian Institute of Technology in Kharagpur, West Bengal. He was to stay at I.I.T. for 14 years, aside from a year's leave in London and a three-year period in Athens, Greece where he worked with the pioneering Doxiadis Associates, after which he returned to Kharagpur as Professor and Head of the Department of Architecture and City Planning. In 1969 he migrated to the United States, first as a SPURS (Special Program for Urban and Regional Studies) Fellow at M.I.T. in Cambridge, Massachusetts, then as a city planner for the City of Newton and eventually as a planner for the Massachusetts Executive Office of Communities and Development, where he worked in the Main Street Program on downtown revitalization of Mass. cities and towns. He also lectured at the Boston Architectural Center. When his wife and daughters joined him in 1970, he moved first to Brookline, then to Newton, and, upon retirement in 1993, settled with Gladys in Amherst. After retirement he returned to his first passion, painting, which he had kept up throughout his life, filling his home with beauty. He was a true Renaissance man: a lifelong reader, always with his head in a book, but also an avid gardener. For many years he practiced yoga regularly. He made toys for his children and most of the furniture for his family, taught himself leatherwork, loved philosophical and political discussions, music, swimming, tennis, and cooking, and was a staunch Democrat, making sure to vote, by absentee ballot, even during his last illness. He leaves behind Gladys, his loving wife of 63 years; daughters Josna Rege, in Amherst and Sally Rege Carroll, in North Reading, Massachusetts; grandsons Nikhil, in New York City, and Tyler, also from North Reading, currently studying at UMass Amherst; sisters Kumud Rege and Sunita Kulkarni, and brothers Prabhakar and Sadanand Rege, all in Mumbai, India; sons-in-law Andrew and Kevin, many loving nieces and nephews, brothers- and sisters-in law, and fast friends in India, England, and the United States. A great loss to us all, but a life well lived. Beers and Story Belchertown Funeral Home has been entrusted with the arrangements.

Good Evening!

The efforts to renovate the standards of the Indian Railways, one of the world's largest rail networks, have been set into motion with IIT Kharagpur being roped in to bring about a marvelous change. The proposed ideas, once implemented, will hopefully push us to the top among the more technologically advanced,efficient and passenger-friendly railway networks. 

12 Research projects have been awarded to IIT KGP with synergies between the metallurgical, civil, mechanical, chemical, electrical, and electronics and electrical communications departments being the focal point of the plan. The unique Rubber Technology Centre also has a crucial part to play in this project (for those you know who don't know, yes this is a legitimate place in our campus which does legitimate work).A lot of these research projects are in the final stages of testing. 

Let's hope to see our institute shoulder the responsibility of tackling many other pressing issues and live up to our motto.

For further details, please follow the link below:
http://indianexpress.com/article/education/iit-kharagpur-works-on-projects-to-strengthen-rail-safety-3051841/

story: The Scholars' Avenue shared Metakgp's post.
message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Metakgp's post. Greetings, fine citizens of the realm! We hope your mid-semester exams went well. As the library site was down for most part of mid-semester exams, our site MFQP was also rendered to be down for the first few days, but we found a way out so that we could keep serving papers to everyone in KGP! Now, let's all contribute, and increase the papers MFQP has. Our Paper Collection Drive starts today! We request everyone to submit their mid-semester question papers. Here's how you can contribute - Click, Upload & Send. 1. Take a picture of your question paper 2. Write Subject Code in email 3. Send to metakgp-qp@googlegroups.com And, do visit http://metakgp.github.io/mfqp-source/ Never go to an exam without having had a look at the previous year's paper! Let's all work towards achieving that goal. That's all folks! Have a nice week ahead!

Good evening people,

We hope you are settling back into the routine of attending classes after the mid semester examinations. With the recent introduction of the science of happiness courses in the institute, we have yet another interesting news coming out .

The Defence Research Development Organisation (DRDO) has approached IIT- Kharagpur to put smiles back on the faces of Indian jawans. DRDO will shortly tie up with IIT-Kgp to work out methods that will increase the happiness quotient of Indian soldiers.

“This is an emerging discipline and is going to be one of the key pillars by which human development will happen,” our Director said.

We are excited to see how this initiative pans out in the future.

http://www.hindustantimes.com/kolkata/tech-that-our-jawans-will-have-the-last-laugh/story-UIIhdO8snzVXu556jcqbHP.html

Hey everyone, 

In recent interesting developments, IIT Kharagpur is to offer courses on the science of happiness  starting today (24.9.2016). “We are looking to the next level... First, it was physical sciences. Now, it’s the study of consciousness,” said Partha Pratim Chakrabarti, our Director.

The courses, to be offered at both undergraduate and post graduate levels, will teach science of happiness, stress management, coping with loss and positive psychology. He also made it clear that while the courses would be available to only IIT students in the first year, the institute will consider opening up the programme to non-IITians from 2017. Here's the full story:- 

http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/starting-today-iit-kharagpur-to-offer-courses-on-happiness-3047110/

In recent interesting developments, IIT Kharagpur is to offer courses on the science of happiness  starting today (24.9.2016). “We are looking to the next level... First, it was physical sciences. Now, it’s the study of consciousness,” said Partha Pratim Chakrabarti, our Director.

The courses, to be offered at both undergraduate and post graduate levels, will teach science of happiness, stress management, coping with loss and positive psychology. He also made it clear that while the courses would be available to only IIT students in the first year, the institute will consider opening up the programme to non-IITians from 2017. Here's the full story:-

story: The Scholars' Avenue shared Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur's post.
message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur's post. An RTI filed to the MHRD has revealed that the annual electric bill paid by IIT Kharagpur to the Ministry of Energy & Power Distribution, Govt. of West Bengal, has surged steeply from Rupees 16 crores 18 lakhs in 2011 to an almost double of 31 crores 46 lakhs in 2016. Despite the introduction of several savings and alternative measures like replacement of traditional halogen street lamps with LED, sensor operated lights and installation of solar panels, this sharp upswing whereas can be attributed to an increase in research facilities and functioning of four new halls viz. RLB, LBS, BRH & NVH; it cannot be ruled out completely that the misuse and wastage do not have a colossal rise. The hall and department wise data obtained from the Electric Office unveils that the consumption has increased drastically in almost every hall and department. Many a times we are seen to leave the lights and fans running while we go to the class; not because of our unwillingness but because of our carelessness. We should always remember that there are still 19,706 villages in our India (Data as of 2015, Census Board, Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt. of India) which remain un-electrified even after 69 years of our independence. Around 12% of our population do not know how does it feel to spend nights with lights! We, from Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur urge each one of us to please use the electricity and water judiciously and encourage our friends towards the same. After all, every small contribution counts! समर शेष है, नहीं पाप का भागी केवल व्याध, जो तटस्थ हैं समय लिखेगा उनका भी अपराध। - राष्ट्रकवि डॉ श्री रामधारी सिंह 'दिनकर'

What KGP lacks in the absence of high rises, it compensates in the sheer amount of self-motivated student groups or "societies" as we call them, that cater to almost all kind of students: creative, intellectual, managerial or welfare inclined.

You just have to name it and you'll have a group of people actively pursuing it. But the question remains, how do we know what exists? Or, how many groups are present here in our campus?

This is a question that might haunt one's brain as soon as they enter the campus, but it soon fades into oblivion and one might miss the chance to get into a society that aligns with their interests.

We finally decided to compile a one-stop list of all the campus societies that we know of till date.

Presenting to you in an interactive format that might just make you forgive Mendeleev a bit.

The Periodic Table of KGPian Societies, everybody!

 https://thescholarsavenue.github.io/societytable/

P.S: Any societies that need any edits in their respective sections can ping us, or mail us (thescholarsavenue@gmail.com) with the edits. 
We have only accounted groups that are open to all and are not limited by the Departments and we agree that we might have missed a few nevertheless.
Also, this link is not mobile-friendly yet.

Good Morning Folks!
We hope all your days are running well. The saga of waking up just 5 minutes before class is an everlasting one with consequences that might lead to cycle collisions thanks to some of the new changes in rules around here. But for what it's worth, the IIT tag looms large before you and you might as well put these things at the back of your mind.
But there are some things we do look forward to. Scaling the peak of the most coveted institute in the world, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is everybody's dream. Getting admission into MIT is an objectively quantified pinnacle of achievement. 

Well, that explains the rat race we were put into from a very young age, right? It means that we, with our degrees and achievements, are the ones who are capable of following this road. 
Or does it?

Here is a story that will shatter such narrow conceptions and hopefully rekindle the fire for 'learning' within you. The most important thing in one's life is to question everything and set upon a journey to find the answers. The present system of education is stuck in a deep quagmire of controversy, but in the end it is the passion and interest of a person that will actually propel him/her forward.

Read about the inspiring story here: http://www.hindustantimes.com/education/17-year-old-unschooled-mumbai-girl-malvika-joshi-makes-it-to-mit/story-EQxDf2NFS5TReDc6Ix3iEJ.html
